content.body: Leave my sense of logic at the door eh? :) Sounds like a fun place to hang out.
does anybody know if the WebM subset of Matroiska includes multitrack support? (for caption tracks, additional audio tracks, etc.)
MikeSmith: http://www.webmproject.org/code/specs/container/
MikeSmith: no captions.  you can include multiple tracks, but it's not clear how the non-default ones are supposed to be handled yet.
"Initial WebM release does not support subtitles.
WHATWG / W3C RFC will release guidance on subtitles and other overlays in HTML5 <video> in the near future. WebM intends to follow that guidance."
interesting!
kinetik: but it would technically be trivial to include the subtitling functionality of Matroska into WebM, right?
nessy: fairly simple, yes
got a lot of reading specs to do :)
nessy: i think the main problem right now is that the matroska spec specifies three or four subtitle formats
and they only want one?
ideally we'd want to support one, and that one being whatever is web friendly
I like the "we" in that sentence ;)
lol
any mailing lists or stuff you'd recommend to join? where does the webm community hang out?
nessy: http://www.webmproject.org/about/discuss/
thanks! (not actually that easy to find...)
zcorpan_, where can i find out more about w3c subtitle work?
https://groups.google.com/a/webmproject.org/group/webm-discuss/browse_thread/thread/21ec1286b09e5616#
f1lt3r: i think the work being referred to was removed from the w3c copy of the spec
ok
f1lt3r: but there's http://whatwg.org/html5#websrt
(the previous link was unrelated)
kinetik: thanks for the info
and zcorpan_
nessy, kinetik, the plan is for WebM to eventually support whatever format is specced for use in HTML5, which at this stage, is the WebSRT proposal.
Lachy: that's my understanding too, but it's not clear from webmproject.org
kinetik, I know cause I've been involved in the discussions for the past few weeks
Lachy: on seaotter?
yes
"Overall, VP8 appears to be significantly weaker than H.264 compression-wise"
who's Jason Garrett-Glaser?
one of the lead x264 (an h.264 encoder) developers
ah, OK
<snort> ASS gets my vote for best-named subtitle/caption format http://www.matroska.org/technical/specs/subtitles/ssa.html
Mik eSmith, Lachy: Do you know if there are asian device makers who would be annoyed by vp8. thinking about samsung, nintendo and sony for example. Or do they use chipsets from elsewhere.
karlcow, I don't have any inside info on hardware vendors

the list of people participating to the new webm consortium is missing some companies. Apple, Nokia, Samsung, Sony, it will be interesting to see how it evolves. Let's hope it doesn't turn into another war
dunno know what any of those companies might think in regard to this news
and wouldn't want to speculate
and wouldn't say even if I did know anything :)
hehe
MikeSmith: I wouldn't hear what you would not have to say about it ;)
Hixie: from your perspective, what is the best way to ensure that forms post UTF-8
the most reliable combination I can find is accept-charset, a hidden field with unicode character as value, and _charset_ to validate (if available)
is there anything else?
is this unreliable?
Is the host document UTF-8?
Philip`: yes
Philip`: but the user can change it :/
it seems that accept-charset + hidden field with unicode value results in all browsers (including IE) ignoring user-overridden charsets
I'm asking here because there was a lot of discussion on back-compat in the WF2 days around this topic (from what I can glean)
if I were a tech reporter, I think right now I'd be asking for comments on WebM from some companies with serious business stakes in IPTV
http://kynesim.blogspot.com/2010/04/interesting-times-for-ott-video.html is interesting

"From a royalty regime point of view it's much more important to replace AC3 and MP3 with Vorbis than it is to replace HTML5 with Theora. Particularly since the MP3 licensors, in particular, are apt to charge punitive rates to implementations which take other formats too - this being one reason why IPTV broadcasts generally avoid mp3"
mp3 patents should expire within a few years...
othermaciej: so I'm sure the patent holders will do everything they can to make as much money as possible on them during those few remaining years
I would if I were them
Would the companies not try to extend the life of the patent? http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evergreening
is not a patent law expert
MikeSmith: many of them are also patent holders on AAC and I expect they would not want to scare people off AAC by being dicks about <P3
nimbupani: that's a depressing article
MikeSmithX: evergreening?
one more among the list of things I guess I should know about but would almost rather not
nimbupani: yeah
yeah thats how big pharmas make their money :(
well, everybody's got a right to make money
indian companies making AIDS meds for 1/10th cost were sued out of existence coz of patent infringements
well, that's definitely screwed up then
so big NGOs in Africa get grants to pay big pharmas LOTS of money to get these expensive meds and then give them for free for AIDS victims who are poor.
I guess it could be argued that they are still playing by the rules
and that it's the rules that need to change
MikeSmith: yes, exactly.
this patent law is screwed I think.
I'm sure they use a good part of their profits to lobby against changing the rules
i think so too.
Plus US has all these Free Trade Agreements that let them sue companies in the countries they have FTAs with (for patent infringements)

the carrot in the case of Singapore was visa waiver for Singapore citizens and special H1B category for them, one of the things in return was stricter enforcement of anti-piracy practices (among others).
sounds more like extortion than a carrot

I downloaded the 64-bit Ubuntu WebM build of Opera, but it doesn't support WebM. How do I make sure the app doesn't load libs from the Opera installed from .deb and actually loads from the directory extracted from .tar.gz?
32-bit WebM-enabled MozillaDeveloperPreview on Mac, WFM, on the other hand
hsivonen, foolip should know, if he's around
but I will try the build now, see if it works for me
I'm still on Karmic, FWIW
hi there
there's a problem with the libc version linked in the Linux builds
hi
if you put those plugins in GST_PLUGIN_PATH and do gst-inspect opera_vp8, do you see some plugin load failed warnings?
with ARIA boolean values, does that mean I should have aria-haspopup=true, aria-haspopup=aria-haspopup or just aria-haspopup in html5?
foolip, the build kind of works for me in Ubuntu.
Creap, I think ARIA is different from boolean attributes as defined in HTML
Creap, we gave Last Call comments to that effect
Karmic just might be too old, I built on Lucid
Creap, I lost track as to whether they were addressed or not
foolip, but the audio seems to drop out after a few seconds, and comes back only after I seek.
ok
hsivonen: if that's the issue, then we know about it (too late) and are going to fix it
Creap: it should be =true according to the aria spec, iirc
Lachy: low bandwidth?
no, playing from localhost
well, sort of. Ubuntu running in a virtual machine is accessing the web server running under Mac on the same computer
Lachy: file a bug :) (not in #whatwg)
foolip: http://pastebin.mozilla.org/726083
will do soon
hsivonen: yeah, that's the same issue
foolip: thanks
sorry about that, linux libraries were rushed
looks forward to having WebM in mozilla-central and therefore in my local builds
hsivonen, the patches are in the bugs now. I'm just touching my stuff up for review
hmm, maybe the audio issue is caused by VMWare trying to take a snapshot of the virtual machine, and using a lot of resources. I usually have to wait for that to finish before doing things
doublec: great!
"I didn't patent CSS" heh
I think it's great howcome made that point on stage.
annevk, HÃ¥kon may not have, but Microsoft did :-)
according to the CSS patent disclosures
about http://html5.org/tools/web-apps-tracker?from=4926&to=4927 .. is that constraint meant to be machine checkable?
i think it is
how can you detect "include data blocks"?
how do I determine if an instance of the element contains data blocks?
I can imagine it for certain known mime types
but in general, the validator can't know what the browser would treat as script
(what othermaciej said ... I type too clow)
not for sure anywa
*slow
it can identify JavaScript and known non-script types and that's it
what's the current state of discussion around the Content Security Policy spec?
http://people.mozilla.org/~bsterne/content-security-policy/
have other browser vendors expressed some support for implementing it yet?
I think the WebKit project may be interested in implementing it
but
I dunno how good the current rev is
MikeSmith: i think html5 should specify a dedicated mime type for 'data blocks'
zcorpan_: aye
othermaciej: OK, thanks
no clear statement from vendors
I prefer security features that work more automatically w/ less work by the content author
but clearly the idea of dropping priveleges has a certain appeal right now
good night
'night
are the right people at Opera aware of the content type trouble with http://devfiles.myopera.com/articles/1891/sunflower-webm.html ?
Lachy: yesterday you said something about the performance of WebM decoding with the CPU on 1080p
(the video file is application/octet-stream; should be video/webm)
hsivonen: I can mail the guy
hasather: thanks
according to foolip application/octet-stream should play per the specification
Lachy: Using GL to perform YUV conversion and scaling, we can play fullscreen 1080p using slightly less than one core of my 3-year-old Macbook pro , so it's definitely doable
specification is somewhat unclear on media types; e.g. if a UA supports Ogg Theora and WebM, someone puts WebM as video/ogg on the web, it should still play per spec
which specification?
HTML5
"The MIME type "application/octet-stream" with no parameters is never a type that the user agent knows it cannot render."
ah
interesting, I wasn't aware of that
and fetching resources says

"If the media resource is found to have Content-Type metadata that, when parsed as a MIME type (including any codecs described by the codecs parameter), represents a type that the user agent knows it cannot render (even if the actual media data is in a supported format)"
it doesn't actually say anything about mismatching
annevk: looks like the spec is settuing us up for image/* all over again
not sure whether to consider this broken or a feature
right. magic numbers within image/* work
except for SVG maybe
yeah, SVG is noted as exception
i noticed this about a year ago or so
for images
don't remember if i emailed the list, but at least Hixie didn't think it was an obvious bug as to change the spec
zcorpan_, was there discussion about it too? I though there was
at least in #whatwg, yeah
hum
when did this get added?
adding a requirement for binary sniffing of all media types is a fairly big deal
that is what we're doing
I think we should remove that
I guess Apple advocated it

Lachy: about http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9707 .. the bug-status guidelines that othermaciej wrote up pretty much reserve the "invalid" state for bug reports that are simply spam. I think we are meant to use "worksforme" instead for cases like this one
but all this is based on vague recollections so don't take my word for it :)
I wouldn't mind changing the spec, but would make actually changeing the implemention veeery low priority
Why does http://videojs.com/ have a *fallback* for Opera?
zcorpan_: can you check it out?
roc: at first there were no checking at all in the spec
it was added between april and august 2009
roc: then some checks were added, mostly due to feedback from me iirc
goes to find the exact diff
oh maybe you're discussing something else
foolip, wouldn't it be a trivial change?
annevk: not at all
once we hand off the media to the platform, it doesn't even have the MIME type, it uses only sniffing to set up the decoding pipeline
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=7977
thanks anne
foolip, ah yeah, but the application/octet-stream one should be more doable
annevk: to just not support it?
hsan't looked at the bug
oh, simon's old bug
we already handle application/octet-stream as per spec
that bug report is not very helpful
foolip, right, to not support it
roc, not really, no :/
annevk: why would we want to not support application/octet-stream?
I'm beginning to think that MIME types are just silly
well, it's nice that things aren't served as text/plain I guess
That seems to be a surprisingly common conclusion
zcorpan_, I could be convinced that we want to support lack of a Content-Type header everywhere, but then we should be consistent about it
bah, I'm not writing a manifesto for/against MIME today, life goes on
zcorpan_, e.g. <html manifest> does not support lack of a content type, neither does EventSource() iirc
doesn't really care much either way
we might gain some more friends by getting rid of Content-Type :p
hmmm
hsivonen: the video should work now
annevk: i think there are more effective ways to gain friends :P
I wonder how we handle unknown content-types for video right now
what was the issue with http://videojs.com/ ?
ah, I think we just fail
hasather: thanks
i get a <video> there in opera
zcorpan_: opera isn't on the support list but on the fallback list
zcorpan_: problem with advertising, not code, then
ooh I found the wrong bug?
sorry
looks once more
the actual revision was http://html5.org/tools/web-apps-tracker?from=3497&to=3498
it is not tied back to any bug report or email unfortunately
though you could look in the archives of mailing lists to see if hixie confirmed such a change around 2009-07-30
cannot find something in the whatwg archives so fast
annevk: Do you mean http://article.gmane.org/gmane.ietf.http-wg/4340 ?
(or the public-html equivalent)
(which Google is less happy to find for me)
guess so
TabAtkins, awake by any chance?
TabAtkins, I was wondering if the split between display values is really intuitive enough for authors
TabAtkins, I think we should at least provide some simple shorthands for flex usage
ah, so it was mozilla guys asking for application/octet-stream
and now they wonder why lol
typical that only we ended up implementing it :p
i think the spec is fine as is, fwiw
yeah, paving the path for getting rid of content negotiation and what not :p
on the other hand, it makes me wonder why we'd support media types on the HTTP level at all...
for video
to make videos playable in top-level browsing context without sniffing everything for video
so in a top-level browsing context we'd not play video labeled as application/octet-stream?
not sure
but we wouldn't for text/plain or text/html
"Awesome for legacy browsers like IE9 and Safari." :)
(sorry about the flood flood. eek)
Lachy: Hixie said websrt would be used for chapters also
really?
but it's not a chapter format
http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20100504#l-77
annevk: I'm up now.
What were you thinking?
what are the requirements for media chapters?
and what are the solutions being used today for media chapters?
i'm reading diveintohtml5 and wonder if it is safe to use 'html' doctype and some similar html5 enhancements for a web site (which will be generated by static site generator)?
depends on what you mean by 'safe'
The html doctype is completely safe; it's been usable for years.
that's it will be useful for those users using old IE crap
Many of the simpler new elements can be used, but you have to use the html5 shim in IE, and apply proper styling to them yourself, as they're not officially recognized yet.
gour: yup. it'll kick it into standards mode, which means your css and js will act the exact same as if you had the xhtml1 or html4 strict doctype up there
i plan to use YAML framework which takes care of (almost all) IE 'idioms'
Alternately, you may look at this page for valid html doctypes that will trigger standards mode in all browsers: http://www.xanthir.com/etc/doctype.php
let me see...
TabAtkins: they're not valid
zcorpan_: Really?  I discussed it here in the room, and thought it was valid a while back.
Did something change on me recently?
they trigger standards mode
they're not valid
Ah, right.  Yes.
That's fine.  ^_^
But I will amend my statment in the future.  I didn't mean that sense of "valid".
TabAtkins: http://code.google.com/p/html5shiv/ is the place of html5 shiv?
Yes.
ta
<!dOcTYpE                HTMl   >  is valid though. :)
html5 doctype, myspace style.
msg paul_irish You work for g now, right?
Shit.

finishes /The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet/, wonders what he was planning to do

Although possibly I feel too sad to do anything useful
Finishing good books sucks
(it is also possible that listening to the Eels isn't the most chhering way to recover)
*cheering
Leaving the xkcd book lying around is dangerous. Now my life is soundtracked by intermittent bursts of laughter mingled with the occasional "that is /so/ like you"
Although I guess the fact that I am writing a monolouge about it on irc does provide some truth to the claims
othermaciej: Both 89 and 92 have proposals on them now.
